          BBC star at the centre of £35,000 teenage sex pics scandal 'phoned the youngster twice when he was exposed' in desperate bid 'to get their mother to drop her complaint'
      















        
        The BBC presenter at the centre of the £35,000 teenage sex pictures scandal allegedly phoned the youngster after he was exposed. The 'well-known' star reportedly demanded 'what have you done?' in the call, which occurred last week. He also asked his alleged victim to ring their mother to persuade her to 'stop the investigation' as he began to panic, according to The Sun. 
      
















129

 comments
    














3
 videos

        Nicky Campbell has joined other BBC stars Gary Lineker, Rylan Clark and Jeremy Vine in taking to social media to distance themselves from the sex picture scandal

          'Hooded and marched from my cell I feared I'd be shot... only to be rescued by Roman Abramovich': British volunteer caught fighting in Ukraine reveals how he escaped a death sentence via an astonishing quarter
      



















      
      Briton Aiden Aslin (pictured centre), now 29, was captured by Russian forces in April 2022 while fighting as a volunteer with the Ukrainian marines. In the Mail on Sunday he told how he was brutally beaten by his captors and heard a prisoner being murdered in the next cell. Now in the third and final part of our serialisation of his new book he describes how he was condemned to death in a show trial and saved in an extraordinary prisoner swap by Roman Abramovich (inset). Alongside his fellow defendants Shaun Pinner (pictured in the orange t-shirt) and Brahim Saadoune they stood in a Russian courtroom where they were conned and deliberately deceived.
    














32
 comments
    














24
 shares
    


'Roman Abramovich helped me escape a death sentence'

            Family's devastation as second schoolgirl, 8, dies after Wimbledon crash when 4x4 smashed through fence: Parents say victim was 'the light of their lives who embodied joy, kindness and generosity'
        





















                
                A second child has now died after a car crashed into a school in Wimbledon on Thursday, the Metropolitan Police have confirmed. The child has been named as eight-year-old Nuria Sajjad (left), as her family paid tribute to her as 'the light of our lives'. It was confirmed on Thursday that schoolgirl Selena Lau (right), also eight, had died from her injuries. Police were called to The Study Prep School on Camp Road at 9.54am on Thursday to reports that a car had crashed through a fence and collided with a building (inset).

Fury as Transgender activist who served 30 years in jail for attempted murder tells cheering crowd at Trans Pride march 'if you see a TERF, punch them in the face'





















       
       Sarah Jane Baker was one of the speakers at the Trans+ Pride event in London yesterday and used her speech to call for violence against those critical of trans ideology. She told the crowd: 'I was gonna come here and be really fluffy and be really nice and say yeah be really lovely and queer and gay... Nah, if you see a TERF, punch them in the f****** face.' Baker's speech incited fury on social media and users called for Trans Pride to take a stance against the violence. Labour MP Clive Lewis shared people's anger over the comment and wrote: 'Advocating violence against others is wrong & this is no exception. But as you'll be aware violent language and actions are not unique to one side on this issue. That doesn't justify the above in anyway, but it does require we acknowledge the general toxicity & step back from it.'
     


















40
 comments
    














275
 shares
    


Transgender activist tells crowd 'if you see a TERF, punch them'
















Ukrainian cruise missile attack forces huge ten-mile bridge that links Russia to Crimea - and cost Putin £3 billion to build - to close





















       
       Russian air defences claim they shot down a 'modernised missile from a S-200 complex' in the vicinity of the huge crossing, built in 2014 when Putin annexed the Crimea. One report said this was an interception by the 31st Air Defence Division north of Taman on the Russia side of the bridge. It was evidently downed on the Kerch - or Crimean - side of the mammoth bridge.

Ukrainian missile attacks ten-mile bridge linking Russia to Crimea
















Cara Delevingne hits back at critics after she shut down grid chat with Sky Sports' Martin Brundle, leaving F1 legend furious at Grand Prix





















       
       Cara Delevingne has spoken out following the awkward moment she seemingly left a UK racing legend high and dry on the grid at the British Grand Prix on Sunday. Former British racing driver turned broadcaster Martin Brundle, 64, was covering the live action from Silverstone when the 30-year-old model snubbed his request for a chat. Martin approached the supermodel with a Sky Sports F1 microphone but Martin was quickly told by an apparent security aide that 'she doesn't want to talk'.
     
















36
















908
 comments
    
















'Is that the worst ever Elvis impersonation?' Actor Damian Lewis is mocked on social media for his toe-curling rendition of the national anthem at British Grand Prix





















       
       British actor Damian Lewis has been mocked on social media for his toe-curdling rendition of the national anthem at the British Grand Prix. The 52-year-old, who released his debut album Mission Creep in June, was blasted for trying to impersonate the King of Rock and Roll Elvis Presley during his performance on the Silverstone grid this afternoon. Lewis performed with his band live in the paddock on Sunday and later sang the national anthem alongside a saxophonist. Social media soon erupted with comments about the unique way that Lewis was singing God Save The King, with one brutally posting that he had simply 'butchered' it.
     


















723
 comments
    














1

Damian Lewis is mocked for his national anthem at British Grand Prix
















Britain's Alabama? Not according to the ethnic minority locals in the heart of God's Own Country... After a Labour council-funded report claimed York is riddled with 'casual, systemic and structural' racism, ROBERT HARDMAN finds a very different story





















       
       ROBERT HARDMAN visits the City of York to speak to residents about the conclusions of Inclusive Equal Rights UK (IERUK) group, stating that racism in the city is 'casual, systemic and structural'. Citing multiple disparities in everything from education to employment and policing, with anecdotal evidence, this alarming document, funded by the Labour-run city council, paints a picture of a place closer to Alabama circa 1955 than 21st-century Yorkshire.
     

















         comments

Britain's Alabama? Not according to York's ethnic minority locals
















Belarusian Victoria Azarenka is booed by Wimbledon crowd after defeat by Ukrainian Elina Svitolina before she gives dismissive fist gesture to fans she then labels 'drunk' on Court No 1... with the pair not shaking hands after their match





















       
       Belarusian Victoria Azarenka left Court One to a chorus of boos after losing a dramatic fourth-round contest to Ukraine's Elina Svitolina. The crowd had been overwhelmingly behind Svitolina throughout and produced a deafening roar when she clinched a 2-6 6-4 7-6 (9) victory. The former world number three had been booed at the French Open for refusing to shake hands with Russian and Belarusian opponents but here it was Azarenka, who put her hand up to acknowledge Svitolina before leaving the court, that received loud jeers.

No champagne service for Wimbledon as tournament umpire steps in to urge spectators from opening the fizz when players are trying to take their shots





















       
       This is the hilarious moment a Wimbledon umpire stepped in to urge spectators not to pop champagne while the players were trying to take their shots. Anastasia Potapova (right), 22, was gearing up to serve against 16-year-old tennis star Mirra Andreeva at the start of the match on Sunday. But tennis fans were left highly amused at an interjection from Australian official John Blom (top inset), in what has been dubbed the 'most Wimbledon thing ever'.

            Jeremy Vine threatens legal action against trolls as BBC stars line up to deny they are presenter suspended following accusation about paying teen for sexual photos - while Tim Davie blasts 'unsubstantiated' speculation on social media
        





















                
                Mr Vine, 58, has told social media users who allegedly libelled him that he has screenshotted their 'defamatory' tweets and his lawyer 'will be in touch in the coming days'. The Radio 2 lunchtime programme host, who was one of the first BBC celebrities to deny involvement in the scandal, claims that a defamation lawyer advised him that committing libel is the 'quickest way to lose £20,000.' It comes as Radio 5 Live's Nihal Arthanayake has become the latest presenter to deny the allegations, joining the likes of Mr Vine, Gary Lineker, Rylan Clark and Nicky Campbell.

Jeremy Vine threatens legal action against trolls amid BBC scandal



















            The 28-stone horse thief who convinced a rich aristocrat he was her long-lost son - and sparked the most sensational trial since Charles I
        





















                
                One hundred and 50 years ago, during one of the longest trials ever held in England, a jaunty rhyme was sung on the streets of London. Sir Roger Tichborne is my name / I'm seeking now for wealth and fame /They say that I was lost at sea / But I tell them, 'Oh dear, no, not me.' A man claiming to be Sir Roger (left), the heir to a title and vast fortune, who had long been presumed dead, had arrived in England from Australia - and the rest of the aristocratic Tichborne family was fighting a furious legal battle to have him declared a fraudster. The man turned out to be Arthur Orton, also called Fatty Orton (right). The British public lapped it up. Everything about the tale was outrageous and scandalous: it had romance, sex, snobbery, slavery, drama, lies and unimaginable sums of money. Now the author Zadie Smith (inset) has seized on the story, reinventing it in a novel called The Fraud, set to be published this autumn.

            Behind the walls of Camelot: Fascinating new book lays bare the triumphs and tragedies that unfolded inside the iconic Kennedy estate in Hyannis Port - where JFK's father Joe seduced Gloria Swanson and Jackie O retreated to grieve her husband's death
        





















                
                Back when the world was their oyster, Hyannis Port and the briny coast of New England was the Kennedy family's oyster bed. Now, a new book (inset) details the secret lives and history of the American dynasty inside their elusive compound in Hyannis Port, Massachusetts, from the golden age of Camelot to their tragic 'Kennedy curse.' The home is where John Kennedy took his new fiance Jacqueline Bouvier to meet his family for the first time in 1953 (top right). It's where the family collected after every Thanksgiving to play touch football on the front lawn. And where they grieved the deaths of their eldest brother, Joe Jr. - the one destined for greatness- who died in WWII; and their sister, Kick Kennedy whose plane crashed in France with her married lover on board. It's where the family mourned the assassinations of President John F. Kennedy in 1963, and Bobby Kennedy in 1968, and spotlights how Jackie kicked off the myth of Camelot.
